episode: Ep-62 Behind the Tech Kevin Scott Podcast with Xyla Foxlin
text:
XYLA FOXLIN: It’s like the only job in the world that I can think of where I can learn something new every single day, like every single month. And I get to follow whatever whimsy or creative exploration catches my eye. I don’t have to ask a boss about it. I don’t have to justify it, because it’s almost like being curious is my job. And that part is, like, the best.

[MUSIC]

KEVIN SCOTT: Hi, everyone. Welcome to Behind the Tech. I’m Kevin Scott, Chief Technology Officer and EVP of AI at Microsoft.  
Today, tech is part of nearly every aspect of our lives. We’re in the early days of an AI revolution promising to transform our lived experiences as much as any technology ever has. On this podcast, we’ll talk with the folks behind that technology and explore the motivations, passion, and curiosity driving them to create the tech shaping our world. Let’s get started.

[MUSIC]

CHRISTINA WARREN: Hello and welcome to Behind the Tech. I’m cohost, Christina Warren, Senior Developer Advocate at GitHub.

KEVIN SCOTT: And I’m Kevin Scott. 

CHRISTINA WARREN: And today, we’re bringing you a conversation with Xyla Foxlin, a super interesting person who’s only five years out of college but is already making a big impact as a maker, and an engineer, and a person helping build pathways into STEM for women and people of color. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, I have been a devoted fan of Xyla’s YouTube content for years now. And I can’t even remember when I became aware of her channel, but, like, she’s just sort of in the mix of all of this maker content that is my favorite thing in the world to watch. 

And I love her breadth of interest. She, you know, she’s interested in everything from making rockets, like, hilarious rockets, sometimes. Like, she I think has at least got a couple of videos where she launches a Christmas tree, like, hundreds of feet into the air, like, fully lit and like, just the technological challenge of doing that is super interesting. 

But, you know, she does rockets, she does furniture. She does - you know, she’s made videos about making propellers for airplanes. She’s just a really talented maker and does an unbelievably fantastic job, I think, presenting how making is done. And, you know, I think she’s a, like, role model for all of us, honestly. 

CHRISTINA WARREN: Yeah, I can’t wait to hear this interview. I can’t wait for this conversation.

[MUSIC]

KEVIN SCOTT: Xyla Foxlin graduated from Case Western Reserve University in 2019 with a BSE in General Engineering and a concentration in Mechatronics and Creative Technology, as well as a minor in studio art. She began YouTubing in college with the channel Beauty and the Bolt as a way to provide public makerspaces access to free tutorial videos. 

Xyla was also the founder and CEO of Parihug, a company focused on integrating emotions and technology to create a fuller digital experience. She’s previously worked at Disney Imagineering R&D, and iRobot. She was named as one of Cleveland’s Most Interesting People 2017, Crain’s Cleveland Businesses Notable Women in Tech 2018, and 20 in their 20s in 2016, and was crowned Miss Greater Cleveland 2018 in the Miss America program. Her inventions have been featured in The New York Times, The Verge, Mashable, Google Made with Code, and more. 

Xyla, welcome to Behind the Tech. Thank you so much for being here with us today. 

XYLA FOXLIN: Thank you for having me. 

KEVIN SCOTT: So I’ve been watching your videos for a while now. and hopefully eventually we’ll get into, like, how you are interested in the things you’re – or why you’re interested in the things you’re interested in. But, like, maybe we could go all the way back to the beginning and like, how did you get interested in engineering and making in the first place? 

XYLA FOXLIN: Yeah. I think this is what I love so much about the maker movement specifically is I think that when I was a kid, it was sort of like you were interested in engineering or you were interested in art. And it was a little bit gender segregated, but it was also just like those were separate categories. And the maker movement has kind of combined the two. 

But I would say as a kid, I was kind of interested in both, but like mediocre at both of them. I liked tinkering. I liked playing with, like, toys that let you create something. And I think also a big part of it was I was an only child where my parents worked like really, really long hours. So I was kind of home alone a lot with just whatever, recycling, like garbage was around the house. And so, I would entertain myself by making things and like building my dollhouses myself instead of buying them or things like that. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. 

XYLA FOXLIN: Which was also sort of part of the immigrant experience. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. And where were your parents from? 

XYLA FOXLIN: China. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Okay. Yeah. So I want to, like, go back for a second, you know, not to turn this into a therapy session or anything, but you said that you were interested in making things and art, and you felt like you were mediocre at both. 

And, like, this is one of those, like, I felt the same thing myself and still do, honestly. And I’ve got a 13-year-old girl and 15-year-old girl and like, they’re constantly, you know, sort of digging into stuff. And like, their first impression is that they feel like they should be better at a thing than they are when they first start. And like, none of us are good at anything when we start. So like, have you struggled with imposter syndrome?

XYLA FOXLIN: Oh, absolutely. I think as an adult, I have come to embrace that being like moderately good at a lot of things is more useful to me than being a true expert at just one thing.

But there’s this story I tell in probably every talk that I give or like, every time I have a chance to, which is it was my freshman year of engineering school, and I had, like been put in charge of this robot part. I was like the only freshman on the team. And I put it together a couple of weeks before the competition. I had done the CAD myself, and no one had checked it, and nothing fit together. It was like the worst design you’ve ever seen. It was supposed to be like, completely sealing the electronics bay of a robot to regolith, which is like this lunar dirt that’s got some weird static properties. And, like, there was holes in it. 

And so I had this meltdown on the robotics room floor. It was like two in the morning, I was there by myself. And this grad student walked in, and he just wanted to grab some stuff and get out. And he, like, walked into this crying freshman. And he was like, what happened? Like, what is going on? And I was like, I’m so bad at engineering. Like, I’m not cut out for this. 

And he looked at me, and he was like, you played an instrument growing up, right? And I was like, yeah, I’m Chinese. I played the violin. And he said, how many hours a day did you practice your instrument? And I was like, I don’t know, like an hour for 12 years. And he was like, how many hours a day have you practiced building things or engineering, making, any of this? And I said, none. And he said, how can you expect to just walk in and be good at it right away? It’s not a natural skill that you’re born with. It’s something you have to develop. 

And that was like probably one of the most pivotal moments of my engineering career. And I wish that had happened to me when I was like ten instead of when I was 18. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, I don’t know what this pressure is that we place on ourselves, that we must be perfect at a thing immediately. And like, that was some sage advice that you got from a grad student, like, really, really, really good advice like that.

XYLA FOXLIN: Right. Especially like a tired grad student who walked in at two in the morning to not talk to people. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. That’s awesome. 

Well, so, let’s go back to, you know, when you were a kid. Like, what particular things when you were little did you really like doing? You know, so like, I know some of the things you do now. Like, you make rockets. Like you do a whole bunch of casting and, you know, you make furniture. 

XYLA FOXLIN: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: Like, you’ve just got a gazillion things that you do. But like, what was it when you were a kid? 

XYLA FOXLIN: Honestly, none of that. I was a pretty stereotypical girly girl, I think. I liked playing dress up. 

And one of the things that I think was one of the early ones was I – my friends and I got really into those, like, little magnetic animals that bend. Do you remember those? Do you know what I’m talking about? I don’t even remember what they’re called. 

And we ended up – my locker at school became Bendyville, and we built, like, this three story mansion for all of these creatures. And I think I was building the really wacky parts of it, like, you know, the moving staircases and the bathtub that had water in it and stuff like that. But it was definitely a – like, that’s a very, like, dollhouse kind of origin story, I would say.

I got – and I was really into making my own Halloween costumes, and they were always like, really, really elaborate. 

And then I had a fifth grade teacher who was like just a – you know those teachers that will stick with you forever? 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah.

XYLA FOXLIN: She was one of those. She was so cool. She was like a former wildfire firefighter, and she was a rock climber. And she was just so badass in the eyes of all of us fifth graders. And she was really into engineering, and she really wanted to, like, expose all of her students equally to engineering. 

So she applied for a grant for like, Little Lego Robotics Program, the little Lego Mindstorms from the state. And she won it, and she started this like very small, little robotics program. But her class throughout the year was always filled with engineering challenges. And if you like, won enough of them, you’d get a candy bar or something. And so I was like, so dead set on winning the candy bar, and spending so much time on these engineering challenges because I loved them. 

And I think in middle school, like middle school is kind of when a lot of girls stop being interested in math and science. There’s like lots of studies on why that is, but I think instilling it in fifth grade, right before I went to middle school and decided I hated math, it was like enough to keep it going. So towards the end of high school, I could like, reach back to those memories and say like, oh, this is something I want to do. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. Which is awesome. I mean, maybe we could talk a little bit about that, like why you think – or like why you know so many young women get discouraged in middle school. 

And like, you know, I’ve done a whole bunch of stuff over the years with like gender equity and computer science. And like, I’ve got two girls. 

XYLA FOXLIN: I was going to say; they just left middle school, right? But you – you’ve made it through. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. And like my 15-year-old has, without any kind of pushing from us, decided that she’s really excited about medicine and biology. And funny enough, like the thing that she credits her interest in medicine in is like, we, as like very, very bad parents, weren’t paying close enough attention to her network consumption habits. And she, like way too young, binge watched an awful lot of Grey’s Anatomy, which we didn’t watch even as adults. And like we went back and watched and it’s like, oh, wow, this was not appropriate for a 12-year-old to be watching. But like, it convinced her that doctors were cool and like, and that was the thing that she needed to go latch on to this thing.

XYLA FOXLIN: Which is awesome. Yeah. And she’s going to learn about all the adult stuff eventually anyways. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. 

But you know, if a kid gets a chance, whatever brings the chance, but if they get the chance to discover that they are interested in and good enough at something where they just want to go put the work in, like you were talking about before, where you just get better and better and better –

XYLA FOXLIN: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: – like that virtuous cycle is sort of the most important thing in the world. 

And like the thing that – the thing that is so unfortunate is how often kids don’t even get a chance to get on the trailhead, like, they just don’t – you know, like they don’t have your wonderful fifth grade teacher or, you know, like my bad parenting and Grey’s Anatomy. And like, they just don’t figure out that, like, hey, here’s the hook. And that, you know, hard things are hard, like – but, like, you’ve just got to be interested enough to, like,  go do the work to get good. 

XYLA FOXLIN: Yeah, and they have to be in, like, a safe enough environment where they can try things and they can fail. And I think most school systems are not like that. And so, it takes like a family environment or a really special teacher, like you said, to create that environment. And it’s just so hard to do en masse. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. I guess it is with math like hard because the way that we grade mathematics is like, you know, there’s a right and a wrong answer to a problem. And if you get it wrong, like oftentimes you don’t get an awful lot of feedback about what to do to get better. And then you just see the bad score at the end, and it’s like, okay, well, I’m bad at this, which is like wrong.

XYLA FOXLIN: Right. Like it feels very black and white. Until you get up to like, calculus or even pre-calc, where now you’re having – or geometry actually is a great one where, like you start – you could get halfway through proving a theorem or you can kind of get most of the way there, and then it feels like there’s some kind of progress. It’s not like a multiplication problem where you either got it right or you got it wrong. But you have to get through that hump.

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah, I think, too, with math, like I get frustrated with how we teach it because we sort of very frequently introduce the mathematical concepts, absent any kind of motivation for why this thing is important. And like, that’s not how the mathematical concepts are invented. I mean, there’s some things in, you know, pure mathematics that, you know, get invented just for the sake of the math. But like most math got invented because somebody was trying to solve a problem, and like, they needed a way to model something in the real world or, you know. 

XYLA FOXLIN: Right. Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: And like, we just don’t do a good job sharing that with kids early. Unless you have an exceptional teacher. 

XYLA FOXLIN: Right, right. But even an exceptional teacher is working within the bounds of the fact that they’re like, teaching math class. And then the students are going to leave class and go to English class. And they’re going to leave class and go to like science class. And there’s only so much, at least in my experience, there’s only so much the math and the science teachers can do to make their curriculums match up, especially if you’re trying to meet state regulations and state requirements for testing and stuff. 

Yeah, I think even in engineering school, when you think like the whole curriculum is designed to be applied to the real world, the math was still so separate. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. So you got through the gauntlet. 

XYLA FOXLIN: I did. Barely.

KEVIN SCOTT: So how did you decide that you were going to go to engineering school or major in engineering when you went to college? Like, what did that decision look like? 

XYLA FOXLIN: Oh, it was funny, actually. So I applied to college for, like marketing and psychology, I think, which is what the personality test that we took our – our junior or senior year. I don’t know if your kids have taken this yet. They had us all take an online personality test. And it was like based on your personality, you should be a therapist or you should be in marketing or something like that. And so, that’s what I applied for. I was like, I don’t know. 

But I was captain of my school’s robotics team at the time, so I did first robotics, and –

KEVIN SCOTT: That’s awesome. 

XYLA FOXLIN: My – the problem was, I was the only girl on the team for a while, and like, girls didn’t really get to build robots at the time. That was sort of just the general culture of first. And so, I had never built on the robot. 

And when they were assigning everyone a mentor, they asked everyone, like do you want to be on software, or do you want to be on mechanical? And I said, mechanical. And they were like, cool, you can organize all the bake sales. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Ooh.

XYLA FOXLIN: So I didn’t get assigned a mentor. I organized all the bake sales, and I raised a ton of money because like, when I decide to do something, I’m really efficient at it. So I became like, the best fundraising outreach person. 

And all of this was like, I was like, maybe if I do a good enough job, they’ll let me work on the robot. And the problem is that no, if you do a really good job at the thing, then they just give you more of the same thing. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah.

XYLA FOXLIN: So then I took over all the outreach programs, which was actually it was really rewarding and fun. And we’d go into schools and teach, like little kids how to work on Lego robotics stuff.

But then my junior year, I became a captain of the team. And at this point, I had never worked on the robot at all. I had done everything else on the team, including all the video editing. This is how I learned to video edit was I had to make all the team’s videos. And so it had like never crossed my mind that I could actually do engineering because I had sort of been like very subconsciously rejected for the last couple of years. 

But at the same time, I was really involved in the theater program at my high school, and I did tech. And the tech crew was like the polar opposite of the robotics crew. It was all women. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. 

XYLA FOXLIN: And it was all just girls who wanted to play with power tools and build sets.

And then like, the fact that we actually had to run a show at the end was sort of second to -  we were building multi-story sets, they were all being designed in CAD. It was like this really empowering, amazing group of women. And so that’s how I learned how to actually build stuff was building these sets, and how I learned to use power tools. 

And then – I would build the field for the robot. I just wasn’t like building the robot itself. 

But my senior year, we’d all applied to college. We’d heard back. It was the spring musical, and we’re like, sitting around in the tech room, and everyone was discussing what they were going to do for college. And someone was like, Xyla, what are you going to do? And I was like, I don’t know. I got into, you know, these two schools. I gotta decide.

And one – and this girl was like, well, one of those schools doesn’t have an engineering program, so why would you go there? And I was like, what do you mean? And she was like, you’re doing engineering, right? Like you have to do engineering because all of us need to live in your basement when we grow up, because we’re all going into theater. 

(Laughter.)

But it was like a kind of interesting moment where everyone else at the school saw me as an engineer because I was so involved in robotics and I was building stuff. So like, you know, I probably had the skills. And so it was the tech girls that really talked me into it. 

KEVIN SCOTT: That’s super interesting. I mean, super interesting. I mean –

XYLA FOXLIN: They’re all crushing it and none of them live in my basement, for the record. 

KEVIN SCOTT: I mean, look, my kids both love theater, and like, I love this whole, you know, like, the, you know, theater techs are kind of it’s like being on a pirate crew, so whatever you got to do to get the thing done. And I love it.

XYLA FOXLIN: So fun.

KEVIN SCOTT: You know, and there are a lot of, like, really famous makers who had that as their path. I mean, Adam Savage was, you know, at a point in his career was like theater tech person. And yeah –

XYLA FOXLIN: You have to think so out of the box because this was – I mean, this was kind of what we always said at Imagineering, but it’s like: To make someone believe in magic, you have to show them something they’ve never seen before, which means that you have to be always at like, the cutting edge of technology. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. I mean, what Imagineering does, I mean, this is a little bit of a tangent, but I think it’s really fantastic because it’s not just like giving people a fantastic experience for the sake of the experience. 

Like, you’re sort of showing them something about like a possibility for a world that might be. And I think it’s really inspiring for kids. You know, they just sort of walk into these environments and like, oh my God, like how to – like, I didn’t know this was possible and how do they do it? And like, I want to do this. Like it’s really cool, that inspiration piece of it. 

XYLA FOXLIN: Yeah. Yeah. It’s a little bit like, you know, when you’re a really small kid and you are believing in Santa Claus, and then you grow up and you realize Santa Claus is – well, there’s probably not small children listening to the podcast – is maybe not real. And then it’s like your parents.

And I think with Imagineering, it’s a similar thing where it’s kind of like when you’re a really small kid, the whole point is that you believe in the magic and –

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. 

XYLA FOXLIN: But I think what makes Imagineering so exceptional at what they do is that as you grow up, the magic doesn’t fade, even when you know it’s not like what it is. It’s just so well executed. And like, the technology is so flawless and seamless, that you can, as an adult, still immerse yourself in that world. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Well, it’s also an important thing for all of us to remember. Like, I think we have this in us when we’re little kids that like, we can believe that the magic is real, like we can believe that the impossible is possible. And you still need that as an adult. Like, I’m sure every day, like you’re encountering things that you thought were impossible or everybody around you thought was impossible. It’s like, all right, how do I make a living as a YouTuber? Like, how do I – you know, how do I go like, build things that I’ve never built before? It’s like, all about, like, you have to believe this, you know, slightly irrational thing that you’re going to be able to, like, make a very hard thing work. 

XYLA FOXLIN: Yeah, yeah. But now as adults, we have, like the privilege of being the ones that get to fight through it and make it work, which is kind of fun. 

KEVIN SCOTT: It is. It’s a lot of fun. 

So you get to college. You go to Case Western, which has a really good engineering school. So talk a little bit about that. Like, how did you choose which engineering discipline that you wanted to go into and like, you know, what was that like for you? 

XYLA FOXLIN: Yeah. There was a huge number of my friends that went into Case being like, I am here to do biomedical engineering. That’s why I’m at this school, which is very famous for biomedical engineering, and that is what I want to do. 

And I was always like, I didn’t even know what BME was until I got here. How on earth did you find this? So I picked mechanical because I wanted to build robots. And that’s – I feel like mechanical is one of the most obvious forms of engineering. Not obvious, but like everyone knows, that’s kind of like the stereotypical engineering, in a way, maybe? If you want to build things.

And then I so I went in actually as mechanical and aerospace engineering because I loved – I’ve always loved airplanes and flight, and I had worked at an airport in high school to like, get my flight hours and do flight training. 

So I did MechE Aero and like, pretty quickly realized that I didn’t want to do aero because I actually didn’t care about why the planes flew; I just liked flying the planes. 

And so, I switched aero to electrical because I wanted to be able to like, work on an entire robotic system rather than just the mechanical part of it. Because it was kind of the integration of the two that got me really excited. 

But I don’t think I declared that until – and I didn’t do a full electrical degree. I did like 75, 80% of a mechanical degree, and then like 20% of an electrical degree, and into a combined degree.

KEVIN SCOTT: Awesome. And so, you know, what was your experience like? I know – I know a bunch of folks who have gone to get MechE degrees or double degrees. Yeah, and like my I’m a computer scientist by training. But like, I know a bunch of folks who go to engineering school and they get trained in a flavor of engineering, which is like you sit in, you know, like you got a bunch of software you’re using and like, you sort of think about what you’re building, but you don’t do as much building as you actually might like. 

I have a good friend’s daughter who just, you know, a few years ago graduated with a MechE degree from like, a very good engineering school and turned down lots and lots of jobs that were about, you know, sitting in a cubicle doing CAD work, just because she wanted to work in a machine shop somewhere. Which –

XYLA FOXLIN: Yeah.

KEVIN SCOTT: – you know, has been a great choice for her, given what she enjoys doing. 

XYLA FOXLIN: Good.

KEVIN SCOTT: So I don’t know what that’s been –

XYLA FOXLIN: I hope she’s happy.

KEVIN SCOTT: – what – what that was like for you. 

XYLA FOXLIN: Yeah. I had a pretty similar experience, where I’ve never been good at school. Like, I was never good at classroom learning. I have to physically do something to really understand it, or I have to apply something to a project, and then I’ll like, really understand why or how something works.

And so, classes in college were a struggle, and I kind of early on in college decided, I mean, I knew I didn’t want to go to grad school. I just wanted to work in industry and be able to like, physically build stuff. 

So I was kind of like, all I have to do is pass. I don’t need to get straight A’s because I’m not applying to anything with my grades. I’d rather be applying to things with a killer portfolio and be doing the thing I want to be doing in the first place, because I think college is – the value of college is less about the classes themselves and more the environment that you get to live in for four years or five years. And you get access to like machine shops and labs and student organizations and clubs and competitions that are only available to college students. 

So I – my attendance was like maybe mediocre, but I spent a lot of time in the robotics lab or in the makerspace that I worked at, learning that way. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah.

XYLA FOXLIN: So I kind of had to find my own way there. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Yeah. Which, you know, I think makes a lot of sense. 

So you went to school, you got a great education, and then you’re trying to figure out what to go do. 

And like at this point, like in school, you’re making YouTube videos already. You’ve learned how to edit from high school. Like, and you went and worked in industry. So like, I know for a lot of folks, like particularly these days, like it’s a dream that you know, you can go be a full time maker. You get to decide, like what you make. You know, you go create, you know, a YouTube channel or like, you know, you figure out how to build a community around you.

Like, how did that progression go? Like, how did you decide, like, hey, this is where I want to go work, and then eventually, like, you obviously like, left, you know these jobs and like, you became – well, and actually it sounds like twice, like you founded a company. So, like maybe this is the second time you’ve been an entrepreneur.

XYLA FOXLIN: Yeah. It’s a disease. Run away. (Laughter.) 

Yeah, I had a really – I think I had a really unconventional college experience in that my sophomore year, I was at a hackathon, MHacks, which used to be like one of the biggest hackathons in the country. I think it might still be. And I built this like, really silly little teddy bear project where, like if you hugged one, it was connected to the internet, and then the other one would like gently vibrate out the hug and vice versa.

And so, we pitched it at the end of MHacks, and this VC from the Bay area, it was like two people who had left the Thiel Fellowship to start their own company, were like, if we give you some money, will you turn this into a company? 

And so, we were kind of like, how much money. Will it buy us like an egg for our ramen noodles? And so they gave us $1,000 for free. It wasn’t an investment. It was just like a grant. And they were like, you should finish building this prototype and then, you know, try to turn it into a company. 

So we did that. We ended up winning a competition, launched it at the Consumer Electronics Show like later that year. And – and then that just kind of spiraled into this wild startup experience that I’m glad I had, but I’m glad I’m not still doing. 

And, and that was the first time I kind of dropped out of college. So at some point when our Kickstarter got funded, I left school so that I could work on manufacturing full time. And then eventually, I shut the company down and went back to school. And in doing that, I got more involved in the makerspace that I had worked at through all of college. 

And gender equity has, like always been something that’s really important to me, just because, like I look back at my own life, and I’m kind of sad at all the opportunities that I didn’t have because I looked different than like everyone else who was interested in the things that I was doing.

And the makerspace, when I was a freshman, we were in the basement of an engineering building. It was like one floor, lots of like, really fun toys and tools, but it had received so much grant money, and the end goal was to move it into this seven-story building. 

And it’s amazing. It’s a really cool makerspace. It’s called Think Box, and it’s in Cleveland. But we moved into that building my sophomore year, and all of a sudden, like all of the way that we, as teaching assistants or like people who worked at this makerspace could help people change. And it went from I could sit down with a person and really walk them through how to use the tools and how to do their project, into someone comes in, tells me what they’re trying to do, and I would put them in front of a computer with like a document that just had instructions on how to use that machine. And it’s a very different experience. 

And the thing that I noticed was – and those documents were very overwritten. They were like very engineer-written. So to use a MakerBot, we had like MakerBot Replicator 2s. It was like a 75-page document. Yeah. 

KEVIN SCOTT: Wow. 

XYLA FOXLIN: So you can imagine someone walks in, and they want to like 3D print a little desk ornament for their sorority sister, and now they’re facing this 75-page document that’s like borderline unintelligible because it’s just so overwritten. 

And the thing that I noticed. 

KEVIN SCOTT: That’s a little nutty.

XYLA FOXLIN: Yeah. But there was, like, so much liability and red tape everywhere because we’re also, like funded by like, people. It’s a university, and it’s funded by the state. 

And so, I reached out to one of my friends who was a videographer, and I was like, can we try to make video tutorials for all of these machines and see if that helps?
